articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Morgan Stanley Reigns
articles.snippet: Since Facebook’s bumpy initial offering, Morgan Stanley has been involved in 47 technology public offerings with a total value of $23.4 billion.
articles.abstract: Since Facebook’s bumpy initial offering, Morgan Stanley has been involved in 47 technology public offerings with a total value of $23.4 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street analyst-turned-blogger Henry Blodget called it “a disaster.” The Wall Street Journal labeled it a “botched offering.” And after Facebook’s much-criticized initial public offering in May 2012, Morgan Stanley’s vaunted technology investment banking team, the lead underwriter on the deal, looked as if it were down for the count.

articles.headline: Supersize Motor Homes Can Be a Good Way to Go, or Stay
articles.snippet: They may be expensive, but owners say they open up many living and traveling opportunities.
articles.abstract: They may be expensive, but owners say they open up many living and traveling opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — Suzi and Edmund Kuehn parked their 41-foot motor home in Flint, Mich., on a Saturday night four years ago. The next morning, Ms. Kuehn’s ex-husband called from Dallas and told her their 31-year-old son, Leslie, who had been fighting plasma cell leukemia, had died.

articles.headline: Paul Diverges From His Party Over Voter ID
articles.snippet: Senator Rand Paul broke with fellow Republicans by saying that the focus on stricter voting laws to crack down on fraud alienates African-Americans and hurts the party.
articles.abstract: Senator Rand Paul broke with fellow Republicans by saying that the focus on stricter voting laws to crack down on fraud alienates African-Americans and hurts the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky broke Friday with fellow Republicans who have pushed for stricter voting laws as a way to crack down on fraud at the polls, saying that the focus on such measures alienates and insults African-Americans and hurts the party.

articles.headline: A Successor to ‘Colbert’ Is Named
articles.snippet: The Emmy-winning “Colbert Report” will be succeeded by “The Minority Report,” starring Larry Wilmore, a performer who has been a regular on “The Daily Show.”
articles.abstract: The Emmy-winning “Colbert Report” will be succeeded by “The Minority Report,” starring Larry Wilmore, a performer who has been a regular on “The Daily Show.”
articles.lead_paragraph: What comes after “The Colbert Report”?

articles.headline: Apple’s Pursuit of Beats May Foretell a Shift
articles.snippet: Apple, which has been hesitant to enter the streaming market, could finally be taking the plunge.
articles.abstract: Apple, which has been hesitant to enter the streaming market, could finally be taking the plunge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has streaming music’s moment in the mainstream finally come? Or is it here already, and has Apple — once the great innovator of music technology — finally caught on?

articles.headline: U.S. Officers Kill Armed Civilians in Yemen Capital
articles.snippet: A United States Special Operations commando and a C.I.A. officer killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them in the capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.
articles.abstract: A United States Special Operations commando and a C.I.A. officer killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them in the capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A United States Special Operations commando and a Central Intelligence Agency officer in Yemen shot and killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them while the Americans were in a barbershop in the country’s capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.

articles.headline: Writers Feel an Amazon-Hachette Spat
articles.snippet: Amazon’s secret campaign to discourage customers from buying books by Hachette, one of the big New York publishers, burst into the open on Friday.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s secret campaign to discourage customers from buying books by Hachette, one of the big New York publishers, burst into the open on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s biggest bookstore is a bit smaller these days.

articles.headline: Hardship Makes a New Home in the Suburbs
articles.snippet: The suburbs east of Los Angeles were once a magnet for restless newcomers with big aspirations, but jobs never really followed. Today, poverty is growing faster in suburban areas than in cities or rural areas.
articles.abstract: The suburbs east of Los Angeles were once a magnet for restless newcomers with big aspirations, but jobs never really followed. Today, poverty is growing faster in suburban areas than in cities or rural areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORENO VALLEY, Calif. — The freeway exits around here are dotted with people asking for money, holding cardboard signs to tell their stories. The details vary only slightly and almost invariably include: Laid off. Need food. Young children.

articles.headline: Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, and Lately, Coding
articles.snippet: Schools are signing up to teach computer coding, which some view as a basic skill for today, and the tech industry-backed group Code.org is pushing basic coding even for the very young.
articles.abstract: Schools are signing up to teach computer coding, which some view as a basic skill for today, and the tech industry-backed group Code.org is pushing basic coding even for the very young.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILL VALLEY, Calif. — Seven-year-old Jordan Lisle, a second grader, joined his family at a packed after-hours school event last month aimed at inspiring a new interest: computer programming.

articles.headline: 2 Yemenis Shot by Americans Are Linked to Qaeda Cell
articles.snippet: New details emerged about a shooting last month in which the Obama administration said two Americans from the U.S. Embassy killed armed Yemenis who were trying to kidnap them.
articles.abstract: New details emerged about a shooting last month in which the Obama administration said two Americans from the U.S. Embassy killed armed Yemenis who were trying to kidnap them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The kidnappers pulled up in a pickup truck outside the Taj barbershop in an upscale neighborhood here in the Yemeni capital. One held an AK-47 assault rifle and the other carried a stun gun. As the men went inside, nearby shopkeepers heard shots.
articles.byline: By Shuaib Almosawa and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Defending the Open Internet
articles.snippet: As the Federal Communications Commission prepares to address “net neutrality,”  the professor who coined the phrase is influencing the debate.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Communications Commission prepares to address “net neutrality,”  the professor who coined the phrase is influencing the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The future of the Internet — which means the future of communications, culture, free speech and innovation — is up for grabs.

articles.headline: Making Ends Meet at Walmart
articles.snippet: In a rough year for many of its shoppers, adjusted financial results meant higher incentive pay for some of its executives.
articles.abstract: In a rough year for many of its shoppers, adjusted financial results meant higher incentive pay for some of its executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: This has not been a good year for Walmart shareholders. Amid a torrid market over the last 12 months, this giant retailer’s stock has flatlined, reflecting a slowdown in sales growth.

articles.headline: A Soldier’s War on Pain
articles.snippet: After turning away from prescribed narcotics, a wounded Army sergeant has found hope. And some doctors see lessons for the business of long-term pain management.
articles.abstract: After turning away from prescribed narcotics, a wounded Army sergeant has found hope. And some doctors see lessons for the business of long-term pain management.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years and a lifetime ago, a new war began for Sgt. Shane Savage.

articles.headline: China Says Goodbye in the Key of G: Kenny G
articles.snippet: For years, Kenny G’s saxophone instrumental “Going Home” has been piped into shopping malls, schools, train stations and gyms in China as a signal to the public that it is time, indeed, to go.
articles.abstract: For years, Kenny G’s saxophone instrumental “Going Home” has been piped into shopping malls, schools, train stations and gyms in China as a signal to the public that it is time, indeed, to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — There are many things about modern China that defy easy explanation: parents posing their children next to live tigers, the sight of grown women wearing furry cat-ear headbands while shopping, the performance-art-like spectacle of strangers napping together in Ikea display beds.

articles.headline: Ukraine Vote on Separation Held in Chaos
articles.snippet: Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote and said they would not recognize the results.
articles.abstract: Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote and said they would not recognize the results.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Separatists in two provinces of eastern Ukraine conducted chaotic and sometimes violent plebiscites on Sunday that offered voters just one question about self-rule, while raising many more about where events in the region were headed.

articles.headline: Stepping Up to a Host Spot
articles.snippet: Larry Wilmore, a seasoned television writer and producer and “Daily Show” regular, prepares to lead his own commentators on “The Minority Report With Larry Wilmore.”
articles.abstract: Larry Wilmore, a seasoned television writer and producer and “Daily Show” regular, prepares to lead his own commentators on “The Minority Report With Larry Wilmore.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Larry Wilmore, named on Friday as host of “The Minority Report,” the show that will fill the 11:30 p.m. slot on Comedy Central, thought the time had passed for him to receive his own late-night show.

articles.headline: Warnings Along F.C.C.’s Fast Lane
articles.snippet: Time and again, when the government tries to insert itself between the Internet and its users, it gets clobbered. This could end up the same way.
articles.abstract: Time and again, when the government tries to insert itself between the Internet and its users, it gets clobbered. This could end up the same way.
articles.lead_paragraph: The next time the loudmouth in the next cubicle interrupts you with yet another recap of his weekend, just start talking about “net neutrality.”

articles.headline: In Town of Missing Girls, Sorrow, but Little Progress
articles.snippet: In Chibok, Nigeria, where as many as 276 girls were taken by Boko Haram militants, a deep frustration is brewing over the slow government response.
articles.abstract: In Chibok, Nigeria, where as many as 276 girls were taken by Boko Haram militants, a deep frustration is brewing over the slow government response.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHIBOK, Nigeria — The women surged forward, anguish creasing their faces. Many were crying. A collective wail went up, but the officials traveling with the visiting local dignitary pushed them back, shushing them so he could speak.

articles.headline: Overextended, Music TV Shows Fade
articles.snippet: The once wildly popular live music and talent contests on television seem to have run their course, as other genres have in the past.
articles.abstract: The once wildly popular live music and talent contests on television seem to have run their course, as other genres have in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: On television at least, it looks as if the beat doesn’t go on.

articles.headline: Trying to Salvage Remains of Blackwater Case
articles.snippet: The case against five security guards in the 2007 killings of 17 people in Baghdad once seemed clear-cut. But it has been undermined by the prosecution’s own mistakes.
articles.abstract: The case against five security guards in the 2007 killings of 17 people in Baghdad once seemed clear-cut. But it has been undermined by the prosecution’s own mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The team of F.B.I. agents arrived in Iraq to investigate a shooting involving a private company that provided security for Americans in a war zone. It was October 2007, and the name of the company — Blackwater Worldwide — did not yet mean anything to the agents. But what they found shocked them.

articles.headline: IBM Poised for Growth, Chief Says
articles.snippet: In recent years, revenue growth at IBM has been stubbornly elusive, and new technologies like cloud computing have risen to threaten the company’s traditional hardware and software businesses.
articles.abstract: In recent years, revenue growth at IBM has been stubbornly elusive, and new technologies like cloud computing have risen to threaten the company’s traditional hardware and software businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a “rocky time” for IBM. That is the frank verdict from Virginia M. Rometty, the technology giant’s chief executive.

articles.headline: 2 Banking Giants Implore U.S. Authorities to Go Easy
articles.snippet: BNP Paribas and Credit Suisse, facing the threat of criminal charges, made last-ditch appeals for leniency, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.abstract: BNP Paribas and Credit Suisse, facing the threat of criminal charges, made last-ditch appeals for leniency, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two of the world’s biggest banks, facing the threat of criminal charges, are mounting final bids for leniency.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Plaintiff in Silicon Valley Hiring Suit Maligns Deal
articles.snippet: Michael Devine, one of four plaintiffs named in the class action against Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe, has asked the judge in the case to reject the settlement his own lawyers negotiated.
articles.abstract: Michael Devine, one of four plaintiffs named in the class action against Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe, has asked the judge in the case to reject the settlement his own lawyers negotiated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple has more than $150 billion in the bank, eclipsing the combined cash reserves of Israel and Britain. Google, Intel and Adobe have a total of about $80 billion stored up for a rainy day.

articles.headline: In Paris, Benjamin Millepied Rises to the Occasion
articles.snippet: With “Daphnis et Chloé,” Mr. Millepied, who will become the director of the Paris Opera Ballet in the fall, has offered a solid work to buoy his reputation.
articles.abstract: With “Daphnis et Chloé,” Mr. Millepied, who will become the director of the Paris Opera Ballet in the fall, has offered a solid work to buoy his reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — A scenario: a young and unlikely outsider is picked to run one of the world’s great ballet companies. But before he takes over, and under the watchful and perhaps not entirely friendly eyes of the local press and the outgoing leadership, he must create a major work for the company he will run.

articles.headline: Confronted on Execution, Texas Proudly Says It Kills Efficiently
articles.snippet: As lawyers for a Texas death row inmate try to stop his execution, even death penalty critics grudgingly agree that Texas kills with efficiency.
articles.abstract: As lawyers for a Texas death row inmate try to stop his execution, even death penalty critics grudgingly agree that Texas kills with efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. — If Texas executes Robert James Campbell as planned on Tuesday, for raping and murdering a woman, it will be the nation’s first execution since Oklahoma’s bungled attempt at lethal injection two weeks ago left a convicted murderer writhing and moaning before he died.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Nigerian Girls Seen in Video From Militants
articles.snippet: If genuine, the video would be the first public glimpse of the girls since they were seized on April 14 from a school in Nigeria’s far northeast.
articles.abstract: If genuine, the video would be the first public glimpse of the girls since they were seized on April 14 from a school in Nigeria’s far northeast.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — The fears have been mounting for weeks: that the girls have been sold, married off, spirited across international borders, and perhaps even killed. Their fate has become the focus of intense international concern, with Michelle Obama holding up a placard appealing for their safe return and governments across the globe pledging to help track them down.
